StringWithMarkup.String: SURFACE WATER: During July 1981, methoxychlor was detected in 1 of 5 samples of subsurface water taken from the Niagara River, with a detection limit of 0.0010 ppb(1).  During 1979-81, methoxychlor was detected in 36 of 70 surface water samples collected from Niagara-on-the-Lake at a mean concn of 7 ppb(2). During July 1976, in James River near Hopewell, VA, trace amounts (<8 parts per trillion) of methoxychlor were detected(3). During 1974-75 in Lake Superior, of 16 samples, methoxychlor was detected at a max concn of 0.02 ppb, and a mean concn of 0.015 ppb(4). During 1971-72 in a tributary of Lake Michigan, methoxychlor was detected at a concn of 2.9-89.1 parts per trillion(5). In 1983, methoxychlor was found in 11 of 14 samples taken from Lake Ontario, at a max concn of 0.086 ng/L(6). Methoxychlor residue was detected in river samples collected from 5 locations along the Missouri River at an average concn of <6.4 ng/L(7). Methoxychlor was found in six out of eight collection sites from farms in Gambia and Senegal between May-June 2002 at mean concentrations (range) per farm of: SGH 78.5 (not detected-110.9), Malika 69.7 (not detected-444.1), GNP 88.6 (not detected-354.6), Mbao 143.7 (not detected-510.8), Niaga 34.2 (not detected-259.9), and Dakar 197.8 (not detected-785) ng/L(8). Methoxychlor was detected in water samples from Lake Opeongo and Lake Nipigon in Ontario, Canada collected in Aug and Sept 1998 and 1999, at mean concns of 2.1 and 1.5 pg/L at depth of 4 m, respectively, and 0.9 and 1.1 pg/L at a depth of 24-35 m, respectively(9). Methoxychlor was detected in Britt Brook and Virgin Pond in Canada with concns of one replicate of 5.2 and 6.7 pg/L, respectively(9). Methoxychlor was detected in water and pore water samples from the Guanting reservoir in Beijing at mean concn levels (max concn) of 4.07 (21.6) and 29.3 (67.3) ng/L, respectively(10).

Reference: (1) Strachan WMJ; Environ Tox Chem 4: 677-83 (1985)
(2) Strachan WMJ, Huneault H; J Great Lakes Res 5: 61-8 (1979)

StringWithMarkup.String: RAIN/SNOW/FOG: During 1983, methoxychlor was found in precipitation collected on islands in Lake Superior, at a concn of 0.4-7.4 parts per trillion(1). During 1975-76, in precipitation collected on the Canadian side of the Great Lakes, methoxychlor was detected in 68% of 50 rain samples at a max concn of 45 parts per trillion and a mean concn of 7.7 parts per trillion; in 17 snow samples, methoxychlor was detected at a mean concn of 1.5 parts per trillion(2).

StringWithMarkup.String: Methoxychlor was analyzed for, but not detected (detection limit = 6.5 pg) in 33 surface water samples collected from Port Edward (head) and Port Lambton (mouth) on the St. Clair River (regarded as a problem area by virtue of the heavy concn of petro-chemical industrial complexes at Sarnia) between May, 1987 and May, 1989(1). A study involving 820 samples taken from 49 agrichemical facilities located throughout Illinois, reported that methoxychlor was detected in 3 soil samples collected from 2 facilities at concns ranging from 190 to 630 ug/kg (common range of detection limits = 4 to 100 ug/kg), median 500 ug/kg(2). Methoxychlor was detected in water samples at concentrations of 0.022 and 0.04 ppm from two different sampling sites out of seven total sites that directly receive surface run-offs from sugarcane fields in Kenya, taken in October 2002(3). Methoxychlor loading into Lake Ontario from Niagara River is estimated to be 3 kg/year on suspended solids and <20 kg/yr in raw water(4).

Reference: (1) Stoltz RL, Pollock GA; Bull Environ Contam Toxicol 28: 473-6 (1982)

StringWithMarkup.String: Methoxychlor was added to the head waters of the Twin Falls Canal Co canal system (0.3 ppm) and subsequently determined in water at a location approx 75 miles away by gas-liquid chromatography. Methoxychlor residues peaked at the sampling site 45-46 hr after most of the applications. The highest residue level at that time was 1.4 ppb; the mean peak level was 1.1 ppb. Methoxychlor concentrations pretreatment were less than 100 parts per trillion(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: SEDIMENT: Methoxychlor residues were present in suspended sediment samples collected approx every 2 wk from the Niagara River at Niagara-on-the-Lake between Apr 1979 and Apr 1980, and in three other samples collected from the Fort Erie end of the river July 1979(1). During July 1981, methoxychlor was detected in 1 of 5 suspended solids samples taken from Niagara River water at a concn of 0.015 ppb(2). Methoxychlor was detected in sediment samples from Guanting resevoir in Beijing at concn levels of 35.4-352 pg/g, with a mean concn of 48.2 pg/g(3). During 1980-81, methoxychlor was detected in 11 of 11 total surficial bed material samples collected from the Delaware River estuary at trace levels (<0.1 parts per trillion)(4). During July 1976, methoxychlor was detected in trace levels (<6 parts per trillion detected) in sediment samples taken from the James River near Hopewell, VA(5). During 1971-72, methoxychlor was detected in sediment samples taken from a tributary of Lake Michigan at concns ranging from 0.19 to 175.0 ppb(6). Methoxychlor was detected in sediment samples collected from Fiji at concns ranging from <0.17 to 1.50 ng/g dry wt (detection limit = 0.03 ng/g)(7). Concn of methoxychlor in sediments from Taiwan's Da-han River and Erh-jen River were <0.3 to 2.85 and <0.3 to 7.39 ng/g dry weight, respectively(8). Methoxychlor was detected in 2 of 45 sediment samples from creeks in Illinois in 2003, at a concn range of 1.3-1.9 ug/kg(9). Methoxychlor reached a concn of 117 and 190 ng/g dry weight in sediment samples from two water bodies with high inputs of irrigation return flow, collected in April 2003 in California's Central Valley(10). Methoxychlor was detected in 2 of 54 sediment samples collected from Sparta, IL at mean concn of 1.59 ug/kg, ranging from 1.29-1.89 ug/kg(11).

Reference: (1) IARC; Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Man. Geneva: World Health Organization, International Agency for Research on Cancer, 1972-PRESENT. (Multivolume work). Some Halogenated Hydrocarbons. 20: 262 (1979)

StringWithMarkup.String: SOIL: During a US National Soils Monitoring Program, methoxychlor was detected in 1 of 1,729 cropland soil samples at a concn of 0.28 ppb(1); in surface soil samples from 31 apple orchards, methoxychlor was detected at a concn range of 0-4 ppb(1). Two months after pesticide application in Kenya, methoxychlor was detected in soil samples (characterized as clay: 2.07% OC, pH 6.08, clay, sand and silt content of 68%, 28% and 12%, respectively) with a minimum concn of 1.026 ppm(2). Methoxychlor was found in soil in eight out of nine collection sites from farms in Gambia and Senegal between May-June 2002 at mean concs (range) at each farm of: 2.1 (not detected-8.8), 1.1 (not detected-10.9), 0.7, 0.3, 6.9 (not detected-30.7), 1.1, 1, and 0.4 ng/g(3). Methoxychlor was detected in 5 of 36 crop soils (loamy sand soil) from British Columbia, Canada, at a mean concn of 0.23 mg/kg dry weight, ranging from <0.02 to 0.40 mg/kg(4).

StringWithMarkup.String: Methoxychlor was detected in US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Total Diet Studies during Oct 1980 to March 1982 in the following amounts: in the adult diet, 1.5% of 324 food composites; 2 of 27 dairy product samples at a concn of 0.001-0.004 ppm; 1 of 27 grain and cereal product samples at a concn of 0.002 ppm; 2 of 27 legume and vegetable samples at a concn of 0.008-0.022 ppm(1). Methoxychlor was detected in an infant diet at 1.8% of 143 composites, 1 of 13 whole milk samples in a trace amount, 2 of 13 other dairy and dairy substitute samples at a concn of 0.014 ppm; in a toddler diet, methoxychlor was detected at 2.1% of 143 composites, 1 of 13 whole milk samples in a trace amount, 1 of 13 other dairy and dairy substitutes at a concn of 0.004 ppm, and in 1 of 13 grain and cereal products at a concn of 0.003 ppm(2). In an adult diet, methoxychlor was detected in 2.1% of 240 composite samples taken during Oct 1979 to Sept 1980 (methoxychlor detected in dairy products, meat, fish and poultry)(3). In an infant diet, methoxychlor was detected in 1.8% of 110 food composites (methoxychlor detected in whole milk, other dairy and dairy substitutes); in a toddler diet, methoxychlor was detected in 3.6% of 110 food composites (methoxychlor detected in whole milk, other dairy and dairy substitutes, fruit and fruit juices)(4). In an adult diet, methoxychlor was detected in 0.42% of 240 composite samples taken during Oct 1978 to 1979(5). In an infant diet, methoxychlor was detected in 0.91% of 110 food composites; in a toddler diet, 2.7% of 110 food composites were positive(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: Methoxychlor was detected 50 times in 24 food samples collected from 37 market basket surveys between 1982 and 1991 at an average concn of 0.0162 ug/g(1). Data contributed from 10 state food laboratories (CA, FL, IN, MA, MI, NC, NY, OR, VA, WI) for the FOODCONTAM database indicated that methoxychlor was detected 5 (0.035%) and 13 (0.099%) times in 13,980 food samples collected in fiscal years 1988 and 1989, respectively(2). Methoxychlor was detected in less than 1% of 598 domestic rice samples at a maximum concn of 0.18 ppm; rice samples were collected by the US FDA between 1993 and 1994(3). Methoxychlor was detected in strawberries grown in Ontario, Canada, 1983-84(4). During 1971, methoxychlor was detected in 0.4 of 1,803 poultry samples at a concn of 0.01-0.5 ppm (fat basis)(5). Methoxychlor was detected in 38% of food samples in six out of nine collection sites from farms in Gambia and Senegal between May-June 2002 in the following foods (mean concentration in ng/g fresh weight): cabbage (0.4) from BHG; carrot (0.31) from Mboro; turnip (2.43), eggplant (10.6), cabbage (9.3), onion (8.61) and tomato (0.07) from Niaga; lettuce (1.52) and cabbage (0.56) from SGH; sweet pepper (0.77), and cabbage (2.37) from Mbao; sweet pepper (0.7), tomato (2.96), cabbage (6.85) and eggplant (3.9) from LHG(6).

StringWithMarkup.String: Methoxychlor residues on American elm treated with 12.5% MeO-DDT spray were as follows: on trees sprayed 1 year previously: 84.0 mg/kg was found on twigs and 6.0 mg/kg was found in soil under the elm; 3 days after treatment: 260.0 mg/kg was found on twigs, 112.8 mg/kg was found on leaves, and 7.8 mg/kg was found in soil under the elm. 130 days after treatment: 72.6 mg/kg was found on twigs, 0.5 mg/kg on leaves and 1.8 mg/kg was found in soil under elm. Residues on American elm treated with 16.25% MeO-DDT spray were as follows: on trees sprayed 1 year previously: 20.5 mg/kg was found on twigs and 0.4 mg/kg was found in soil under the elm; 3 days after treatment: 195.2 mg/kg was found on twigs, 161.2 mg/kg was found on leaves, and 2.9 mg/kg was found in soil under the elm. 130 days after treatment: 32.0 mg/kg was found on twigs, 0.5 mg/kg on leaves and 1.0 mg/kg was found in soil under elm. /From table/

StringWithMarkup.String: Pesticide analyses were completed on fat and muscle samples of 750 fish collected from 11 major lakes and rivers in Alberta. Methoxychlor was frequently found in goldeye from the North Saskatchewan River but not recorded in fish from any other lake or river. Its presence in goldeye, a highly migratory species, was probably a result of biting-fly control programs in the Saskatchewan part of the river.

StringWithMarkup.String: During 1974-75, methoxychlor was detected in fish from Lake Huron and Lake Superior at a concn of <0.05-0.17 ppm(1). Methoxychlor was found in chinook salmon eggs from Lake Michigan at a concn of 5.0-82.7 ug/kg, mean 37.6 ug/kg(2,3). Methoxychlor was qualitatively detected in fish taken from Lake Michigan tributaries and embayments(4). Methoxychlor was detected in cultured shrimp from 4 farms in Sonora, Mexico(5). Fish samples were collected from Lake Tanganyika, Burundi, Africa, and methoxychlor was detected in the six of the seven species Boulengerochromis microlepis, Chrysichthys sianenna, Oreochromis niloticus, Limrothrissa miodon, Stolothrissa tanganyikae and Lates angustifrons at mean concentration of 61.5, 41.5, 5.3, 17.9, 15.3, and 6.7 ng/g fat, respectively(6). Methoxychlor was detected in tissue samples from Greenland from 1999-2001 at max concentrations, in ng/g lipid weight: muscle of Arctic char, 16; muscle of shrimp, 32; liver and muscle of snow crab, 86 and 45, respectively; muscle of Iceland scallop, 5.7; liver and muscle of Atlantic cod, 2.2 and 33, respectively; liver and muscle of wolffish, 7.2 and 15, respectively; muscle of capelin, 55; liver of shorthorn sculpin, 22(7). Methoxychlor was detected in bonnethead shark tissue samples collected from 3 of 4 FL estuaries (mean concn, ng/g lipid basis): from Apalachicola Bay, liver (17.28), muscle (2.15), serum (9.0); from Florida Bay, liver (13.61), muscle (6.25), serum (8.90); from Tampa Bay, liver (10.87), muscle (3.35), serum (6.10)(8).

StringWithMarkup.String: Methoxychlor was detected in fat samples from raccoons at a concn of 0.16-36.82 ppb(1). StringWithMarkup.String: Methoxychlor was detected in the liver and blubber from 5 male and 5 female 8-month-old harp seals from southern Labrador in November, 1994 at the following concns: female, 0.07 ng/g wet wt in the liver, 0.41 ng/g wet wt in the blubber; male, 0.10 ng/g wet wt in the liver, 0.68 ng/g wet wt in the blubber(1). StringWithMarkup.String: The concentration of methoxychlor in cow milk and plasma were determined following a cutaneous application of a non-commercial emulsion and an iv injection of a solution containing 5 and 1 g methoxychlor, respectively. The max concentration of methoxychlor in milk, found 2 days after dermal administration, was 0.052 ppm, decreased to around 0.005 ppm 30 days later. A distribution volume greater than 200 times the body volume and a dermal absorption of around 1/5 of the topically applied dose were established.

Reference: Ivey MC et al; J Dairy Sci 66 (4): 943-50 (1983)

StringWithMarkup.String: Nine lactating Holstein cattle were treated twice at an interval of 14 days with methoxychlor as a 0, 0.25, or 0.5% dermal spray, with 2 quarts of spray mix applied to each animal. Residues of methoxychlor in whole milk were as high as 2.0 and 3.0 ppm in samples from the low and high dosage sprays. Residues dropped rapidly after the first few days so that after 14 days, residues were at most only slightly above the sensitivity limit (0.005 ppm in whole milk) of the analytical method. Transformation of the residue data on whole milk into equiv concn in milk fat indicates that max residues may be expected to be greater than 2.0 and greater than 3.0 ppm in milk fat from cows sprayed with 0.25 and 0.50% methoxychlor.

Reference: IARC. Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk  of Chemicals to Humans. Geneva: World Health Organization,  International Agency for Research on Cancer, 1972-PRESENT.  (Multivolume work). Available at: https://monographs.iarc.fr/ENG/Classification/index.php, p. V20 270 (1979)

StringWithMarkup.String: ... Residues /were found/ in milk shortly after cows were sprayed with aq suspensions of methoxychlor. Max level of 0.1 mg/L was found 1 day after treatment, and detectable levels persisted for 1 wk.

Section.Description: Other environmental concentrations reported for this chemical.

Reference: Nat'l Research Council Canada; Methoxychlor: Its effects on Environmental Quality p.35 (1975) NRCC No. 14102

StringWithMarkup.String: Methoxychlor residues in Lake Ontario phytoplankton varied from 23-71 ug/kg, which indicates the extensive accumulation of this pesticide by these organisms.

Reference: (1) IARC; Monographs on the Evaluation of the Carcinogenic Risk of Chemicals to Man. Geneva: World Health Organization, International Agency for Research on Cancer, 1972-PRESENT. (Multivolume work). Some Halogenated Hydrocarbons 20: 263 (1979)

StringWithMarkup.String: Methoxychlor has been detected in the following poultry feeds: soya bean meal (2-53 parts per trillion); corn meal (91-151 parts per trillion); alfalfa meal (7-1947 parts per trillion); and fish meal (15-232 parts per trillion)(1). Methoxychlor has been detected in raw tobacco and in finished tobacco products(1).

Section.Description: Potential way(s) in which people may come into contact with a hazardous chemical.  Examples of common exposure routes are inhalation, ingestion, skin/eye contact.

Reference: (1) NIOSH; NOES. National Occupational Exposure Survey conducted from 1981-1983. Estimated numbers of employees potentially exposed to specific agents by 2-digit standard industrial classification (SIC). Available from https://www.cdc.gov/noes/ as of Jul 20, 2009.

StringWithMarkup.String: NIOSH (NOES Survey 1981-1983) has statistically estimated that 3,418 workers were potentially exposed to methoxychlor in the US(1). The NOES survey does not include farm workers. Occupational exposure to methoxychlor may have occurred through inhalation and dermal contact with this compound at workplaces where methoxychlor had been produced or used(SRC). Monitoring data indicate that the general population may have been exposed to methoxychlor via inhalation of ambient air, ingestion of contaminated food and drinking water, and dermal contact with this compound and other products containing methoxychlor(SRC).

Reference: (1) Lewis RG, Lee RE; pp. 5-51 in Air Pollut From Pestic and Agric Processes. Lee RE, ed. Cleveland, OH: CRC Press (1976)

StringWithMarkup.String: Air samples collected from a pesticide formulation plant in Southern Florida (in 1974) contained methoxychlor at 254.0 ng/cu m(1).

Reference: Nat'l Research Council Canada; Methoxychlor: Its effects on Environmental Quality p.28 (1975) NRCC No. 14102

StringWithMarkup.String: FOOD INTAKE: US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) Fiscal Year (FY) 1981/1982 - 0.004 ug/kg body wt/day; FY 1980 - 0.007 ug/kg body wt/day; FY 1979 - 0.003 ug/kg body wt/ day; FY 1978 - 0.007 ug/kg body wt/day(1). FY 1982-1984 - 6-11 months old 1.7 ng/kg bw/day; 2 years old 6.3 ng/kg bw/day; 14-16 year old females 1.5 ng/kg bw/day; 14-16 year old males 2.1 ng/kg bw/day; 25-30 year old females 1.2 ng/kg bw/day; 25-30 year old males 1.4 ng/kg bw/day; 60-65 year old females 1.1 ng/kg bw/day; 60-65 year old males 1.2 ng/kg bw/day(2). AIR INTAKE: Assumed 20 m3 air respired per day; Jacksonville, 6 ng/day reported for Jacksonville, FL from spring of 1986 to winter of 1988(3). ADI values for 8 age/sex groups estimated from 1986 to 1991 are as follows: 6-11 mo old, 0.0004; 2 yr old, 0.0009; 14-16 yr old female, 0.0003; 14-16 yr old male, 0.0004; 25-30 yr old female, 0.0003; 25-30 yr old male, 0.0003; 60-65 yr old female, 0.0001; 60-65 yr old male, 0.0002 ug/kg body wt/day(4).

Reference: (1) Whitmore RW et al; Arch Environ Contam Toxicol 26: 47-59 (1994)

StringWithMarkup.String: Methoxychlor was detected at a concn of 91 ng/day from 8 market basket surveys collected in Jacksonville, FL from April 1982 to 1984; 100 ng/day from 4 market basket surveys collected from July 1986 to May 1987 and the NOPES (Non-Occupational Pesticide Exposure Study) dietary recall questionnaires for Summer 1986; 40 ng/day from one market basket survey collected in the south in April and May 1987 and the NOPES dietary recall questionnaires for Summer 1986; also, from Springfield, MA, methoxychlor was detected at a concn of 90 ng/day from 8 market basket surveys collected from April 1982 to 1984(1).

StringWithMarkup.String: Methoxychlor was detected in human maternal blood taken from pregnant women in the Jackson and Mississippi Delta areas, 122 samples, 0-2.5 ppb concn range, 0.70 ppb mean concn(1). Serum methoxychlor levels in 15 subjects living in agricultural areas in Honduras ranged from <0.24 - <4.07 mg/L(2). Methoxychlor was detected in 26.9% of human breast milk samples collected from mothers of 62 boys with cryptorchidism, and 68 healthy boys in Finland and Denmark from 1997 to 2001, with one sample <LOD, and 94 samples <LOQ(3).

Literature references related to scientific contents from Springer Nature journals and books. It is based on: (1) the TF-IDF, adapted to chemical structures, (2) location information in the text (e.g. title, abstract, keywords), and (3) the document size.  Springer Nature aims to provide only highly qualitative and relevant content but references of lower relevance aren't withheld as they might contain also very useful information.

Reference.Description: The USGS Health-Based Screening Levels for Evaluating Water-Quality Data contains Health-Based Screening Levels (HBSLs) that are non-enforceable water-quality benchmarks that can be used to (1) supplement U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (USEPA) Maximum Contaminant Levels (MCLs) and Human Health Benchmarks for Pesticides (HHBPs), (2) determine whether contaminants found in surface-water or groundwater sources of drinking water may indicate a potential human-health concern, and (3) help prioritize monitoring efforts. HBSLs were developed by the U.S. Geological Survey (USGS).

Reference.Name: EPA SRS List Classification
Reference.Description: Substance Registry Services (SRS) is the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) central system for information about substances that are tracked or regulated by EPA or other sources. It is a resource for basic information about chemicals, biological organisms, and other substances of interest to EPA and its state and tribal partners. SRS makes it possible to identify which EPA data systems, environmental statutes, or other sources have information about a substance and which synonym is used by that system or statute.

Reference.Name: MolGenie Organic Chemistry Ontology
Reference.Description: An organic chemistry ontology developed by MolGenie and OntoChem to assign chemical entities to structural classes, split into three main subsections: calculated properties, compounds and substructural concepts. The ontology contains chemistry structural classes with a focus on elements and small organic compounds, but not inorganic, polymer, biopolymer, metal complexes, metal organic frameworks (MOFs) and other chemistry entities. The ontology has been mapped to several collections of chemicals, including (a) Chemicals of Biological Interest (ChEBI), (b) the ChEMBL database of bioactive molecules, (c) the LOTUS natural product collection, (d) per- and polyfluoroalkyl substances (PFAS) extracted from Barnabas et al (2022) DOI: 10.1039/D2DD00019A (e) PubChemLite and (f) the ZeroPM Global Chemical Inventory.
Reference.LicenseNote: CC-BY 4.0
